doc.field: EU defence ministers' conference ends without resolution

The defence ministers of the European Union have ended their two-day conference in Vienna without having come to any resolution. They merely agreed to work on concepts for a credible military intervention force to deal with international crises, such as the current one in Kosovo. British Defence Minister George Robertson criticized what he called the laborious and slow decision-making in the EU.
EU promises membership talks for Latvia

The European Commission has given the government of Latvia the prospect of possibly joining the European Union soon. EU-Commissioner, Hans van den Broek has told the European Parliament in Brussels that negotiations with that goal could begin before the end of next year. He said that Latvia had made great economic and political progress. The same could be said of Lithuania and Slovakia, he added, but did not specify any date for talks with those countries. Regarding Turkey, van den Broek said that the government in Ankara must subordinate its army to democratic controls before membership in the EU could be considered.
New federal government: monetary and economic policy must be linked

The SPD-Green Coalition says that monetary policy must also come under consideration when discussing general economic policies. Government spokesman, Uwe-Karsten Heye made the statement following a cabinet meeting, making it clear, however, that no one was questioning the independence of the German or the European Central Bank. Heye said that, nevertheless, it must remain possible to discuss monetary policy in connection with attempts to foster economic growth and effective employment policies. He also added that the Maastricht Treaty does not preclude such a tie.
Donations for Central American hurricane victims

Numerous aid measures have been set up in Germany to help the victims of hurricane Mitch in Central America. Germans at large have also been called upon to make their own donations. The federal government has released an initial sum of 3.7 million DM. The Diakonie, a church-based social welfare organization, has already promised 250,,000 DM. The UN and the World Bank have also pledged their support. The United States has sent helicopters into the disaster area. Cuban and French doctors have arrived in Honduras. Spain is sending aid materials to Central America by airlift. Over 10,000 people are still missing, following the storm; the number of dead has reached 9,000; millions are homeless.
Parliamentary Greens want improvements to tax reform

Those members of the Green Party in the Bundestag have again called for improvements to the tax reforms agreed upon with the SPD. Economic spokesman for the group, Margareta Wolf, said that reducing the rate for the highest tax bracket from 53 to 48.5 percent was not sufficient. She also said that more attention had to be paid to making sure that small and medium businesses were not burdened further. The deputy-chairman of the SPD's parliamentary group, Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier, announced that the tax reform bill will be presented next Tuesday.
Steffi Graf reaches quarter-finals in Leipzig tennis tournament

Steffi Graf has reached the quarter-finals in the Leipzig tennis tournament. She beat Japanese player Ai Sugiyama 6:4 and 6:3. Graf's next opponent will be decided in the match between Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario of Spain and Anne-Gaelle Sidot of France.
